A Transcendentalist, Unitarian minister, and abolitionist. Parker revealed his radical theological position in his sermon A Discourse on the Transient and Permanent in Christianity. He also wrote the anti-slavery essay To A Southern Slaveholder.

personBio.personNote: An American journalist and editor, Patterson worked as editor for The Oquawka Specator and had plans to work with Poe establishing a new journal The Stylus before Poe died. Patterson is sometimes credited as Edward Patterson, and he occasionally used the pen names "Snik" and "Sniktau."

A jurist who served as Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Parsons was a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a member of the American Antiquarian Society. He is the assumed author of Conciliatory Resolutions which helped persuade Adams and Hancock to approve the ratification of the Constitution

personBio.personNote: A Roman playwright of the Old Latin period, Plautus's comedies are the earliest Latin literary works to have survived in their entirety. His plays are mostly adapted from Greek models for a Roman audience.

An American writer, editor, and literary critic, Poe is considered by many to be deeply influential in the genres of detective fiction, science fiction and the gothic. Some of his famous works include “The Raven”, “The Tell-Tale Heart”, and “The Fall of the House of Usher”. Poe was also co-founder of The Broadway Journal and also worked on The Southern Literary Messenger, Graham’s Magazine, and Burton’s Gentleman’s Magazine. Poe sometimes signed his works "E.S.T.G." or "Edward S. T. Grey."

An ancient Greek philosopher, historian, and student of Socrates, Xenophon was known as the "Attic Muse" due to the sweetness of his diction. His writings include Anabasis, Apology of Socrates to the Jury, and Cyropaedia. Also known as Xenophon of Athens.
Full name unknown.

A German and Swiss author and reformer, Zschokke wrote a variety of literary works in addition to his civil service, including Bilder aus der Schewiz, Ausgewahlte Novellen und Dichtungen, and Alamontade.

Coats is Associate Professor of English and Director of the Digital Scholarship Lab. She teaches and researches early- and nineteenth-century American literature, with emphases on digital humanities, archives, print culture, travel and exploration, and the environment.
Front-End Developer, worked on reactive UI behavior.

Doan is an English PhD student at LSU, who has been involved with developing a digital humanities project about Poe since the fall of 2013. He focuses on 19th century American literature and is particularly interested in literary nationalism and gift exchange.

Fallon is a PhD student in English. She is currently studying developments in late medieval semiotics and their impact on contemporary perceptions of British outlawry. Fallon worked as one of the first graduate assistants to LSU's Digital Scholarship Lab.
Gilliland is a PhD student in English.
Johnson is a PhD candidate in History.

Kennedy is Boyd Professor of English, and has published extensively about Edgar A. Poe. He founded LSU's first digital humanities project on Edgar A. Poe, focused on the four main journals that Poe edited. The current project builds from this foundation.
Key, a Metadata Librarian, provided TEI and XSLT support for the project.
Peak provided systems and web development services to the project.
Powell is a PhD student in English.
Tanglao, a graphic designer, provided UI and site design.
Yantis is a graduate student in Library & Information Sciences.
Flanders of Northeastern University's Digital Scholarship Group provided TEI guidance.
